channel.title: JaneBytes Cybersecurity Feed
channel.description: Summarized articles from top cybersecurity sources.

item.title: ZDI-25-483: IrfanView CADImage Plugin DWG File Parsing Out-Of-Bounds Read Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: IrfanView CADImage Plugin; CVE(s): CVE-2025-7251; Summary: This vulnerability allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected installations of IrfanView CADImage Plugin. User interaction is required to exploit this vulnerability, which exists within the parsing of DWG files due to lack of proper validation of user-supplied data.

item.title: ZDI-25-484: IrfanView CADImage Plugin DWG File Parsing Out-Of-Bounds Read Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: IrfanView CADImage Plugin; CVE(s): CVE-2025-7252; Summary: The IrfanView CADImage Plugin is vulnerable to an out-of-bounds read remote code execution vulnerability. An attacker can exploit this by persuading the target to visit a malicious page or open a malicious file, allowing them to execute arbitrary code on affected installations.

item.title: ZDI-25-485: IrfanView CADImage Plugin DXF File Parsing Out-Of-Bounds Write Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: IrfanView CADImage Plugin; CVE(s): CVE-2025-7235; Summary: This vulnerability allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected installations of IrfanView CADImage Plugin by writing past the end of an allocated buffer due to lack of proper validation of user-supplied data. User interaction is required, and the target must visit a malicious page or open a malicious file to exploit this vulnerability.

item.title: ZDI-25-486: IrfanView CADImage Plugin DWG File Parsing Out-Of-Bounds Read Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: IrfanView CADImage Plugin; CVE(s): CVE-2025-7250; Summary: The IrfanView CADImage Plugin contains an out-of-bounds read remote code execution vulnerability that allows attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected installations. User interaction is required, as the target must visit a malicious page or open a malicious file. The vulnerability exists in the parsing of DWG files due to lack of proper validation of user-supplied data.

item.title: New Android TapTrap attack fools users with invisible UI trick
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Android; CVE(s): None; Summary: A novel tapjacking technique called TapTrap can exploit user interface animations to bypass Android's permission system and allow access to sensitive data or trick users into performing destructive actions, such as wiping the device. This vulnerability affects Android 15 and 16 and allows malicious apps to launch a harmless transparent activity on top of a malicious one, remaining unmitigated in these versions.

item.title: Windows 10 KB5062554 cumulative update released with 13 changes, fixes
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Windows 10; CVE(s): One zero-day vulnerability and 136 other flaws; Summary: The Windows 10 KB5062554 cumulative update contains fixes for one zero-day vulnerability and 136 other flaws. It is mandatory and will automatically start installing once checked for updates.

item.title: Hackers Use Leaked Shellter Tool License to Spread Lumma Stealer and SectopRAT Malware
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Shellter; CVE(s): None; Summary: Hackers are exploiting a popular red teaming tool called Shellter to distribute stealer malware. The tool allows offensive security teams to bypass antivirus and endpoint detection and response (EDR) software installed on endpoints, making it a powerful tool in the wrong hands.

item.title: Windows 11 KB5062553 & KB5062552 cumulative updates released
item.description: There are no specific cybersecurity-related vulnerabilities or threats mentioned in this article. The article is focused on describing the new features and updates included in the latest Windows 11 cumulative updates, such as changes to the taskbar, Narrator, and Voice Access. Additionally, the article includes a brief mention of cloud attacks growing more sophisticated but does not provide any specific details or recommendations for mitigating these threats.

item.title: Microsoft July 2025 Patch Tuesday fixes one zero-day, 137 flaws
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft SQL Server; CVE(s): CVE-2025-49719; Summary: A publicly disclosed zero-day vulnerability in Microsoft SQL Server allows a remote, unauthenticated attacker to access data from uninitialized memory. The flaw can be fixed by installing the latest version of Microsoft SQL Server and by installing the Microsoft OLE DB Driver 18 or 19.

item.title: Anatsa Android Banking Trojan Hits 90,000 Users with Fake PDF App on Google Play
item.description: An Android banking malware campaign, known as Anatsa, has targeted users in North America by distributing a trojan disguised as a "PDF Update" to a document viewer app. The malware can steal credentials through overlay and keylogging attacks, conduct Device-Takeover Fraud (DTO), and receive a dynamic list of targeted financial institutions from an external server.

item.title: Android malware Anatsa infiltrates Google Play to target US banks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Hybrid Cars Simulator, Drift & Racing; CVE(s): None; Summary: The Anatsa banking trojan was found in Google Play as an app posing as a PDF viewer that had over 50,000 downloads. The malware becomes active immediately after installation and tracks users launching North American banking apps, serving overlays, keylogging, or automating transactions.

item.title: Overcoming Technical Barriers in Desktop and Application Virtualization
item.description: The article discusses the challenges and risks associated with desktop and application virtualization, including security risks from exposed firewall ports, lateral movement threats, and network performance issues. It highlights the importance of implementing a Zero Trust architecture and Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) to mitigate these risks.

item.title: Malicious Chrome extensions with 1.7M installs found on Web Store
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Google Chrome Web Store; CVE(s): None; Summary: Malicious extensions with over 1.7 million downloads in the Google Chrome Web Store can track users, steal browser activity, and redirect to potentially unsafe web addresses. The extensions, posing as legitimate tools, were discovered by researchers at Koi Security and reported to Google.

item.title: Malicious Pull Request Targets 6,000+ Developers via Vulnerable Ethcode VS Code Extension
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Visual Studio Code (VS Code) extension Ethcode; CVE(s): None; Summary: A supply chain attack compromised the Ethcode VS Code extension, which has been installed over 6,000 times. The attacker added a malicious dependency called "keythereum-utils" that downloads an unknown second-stage payload, potentially capable of stealing cryptocurrency assets or poisoning smart contracts.
FYSA: This is an example of a broader trend of software supply chain attacks, where attackers weaponize public repositories like GitHub and npm to deliver malware directly into developer environments. The attack highlights the importance of secure development practices and the need for continuous monitoring and auditing of open-source dependencies.

item.title: Emerson ValveLink Products
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Emerson ValveLink Products; CVE(s): CVE-2025-52579, CVE-2025-50109, CVE-2025-46358, CVE-2025-48496, CVE-2025-53471; Summary: Successful exploitation of these vulnerabilities could allow an attacker with access to the system to read sensitive information stored in cleartext, tamper with parameters, and run un-authorized code. The affected products are ValveLink SOLO, ValveLink DTM, ValveLink PRM, and ValveLink SNAP-ON, all versions prior to ValveLink 14.0.

item.title: CISA Releases One Industrial Control Systems Advisory
item.description: CISA released an Industrial Control Systems (ICS) advisory on July 8, 2025, providing timely information about current security issues, vulnerabilities, and exploits surrounding ICS. The advisory is for Emerson ValveLink Products.

item.title: 5 Ways Identity-based Attacks Are Breaching Retail
item.description: The article discusses recent high-profile data breaches in retail, where attackers exploited overprivileged access and unmonitored service accounts using social engineering tactics. The attacks targeted third-party customer service providers, resulting in the exposure of customer data, including names, email addresses, and order details.

item.title: RondoDox Botnet Exploits Flaws in TBK DVRs and Four-Faith Routers to Launch DDoS Attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: TBK Digital Video Recorders (DVRs) - DVR-4104 and DVR-4216; Four-Faith routers - F3x24 and F3x36; CVE(s): CVE-2024-3721, CVE-2024-12856; Summary: Medium-severity command injection vulnerabilities in TBK DVRs and Four-Faith routers allow attackers to deploy different Mirai botnet variants. The flaws have been publicly disclosed and are actively being targeted, posing serious risks to device security and overall network integrity.

item.title: BaitTrap: Over 17,000 Fake News Websites Caught Fueling Investment Fraud Globally
item.description: A large-scale scam operation utilizing fake news websites (Baiting News Sites) has been discovered, targeting users across 50 countries with online investment fraud. The scammers use sponsored ads and fake articles to lure victims into fraudulent trading platforms, followed by a two-phase structure of building trust and extracting maximum value before the victim realizes it's a trap.

item.title: GoldMelodys Hidden Chords: Initial Access Broker In-Memory IIS Modules Revealed
item.description:
This article appears to be a threat brief on an Initial Access Broker (IAB) group known as TGR-CRI-0045, which is leveraging in-memory IIS techniques for persistent access. The article discusses the group's use of ASP.NET View State deserialization vulnerabilities and its exploitation of exposed Machine Keys.
The article provides details on the group's tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), including the use of reflective .NET assemblies, TxPortMap tooling, and GodPotato privilege escalation technique. It also discusses the group's post-exploitation activities, such as code injection attacks using publicly disclosed ASP.NET machine keys.
The article concludes by highlighting the need for organizations to prioritize identifying and remediating compromised Machine Keys, as outlined by Microsoft. It also mentions that Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from these threats through various products and features.
Overall, this article is not discussing a specific vulnerability (software, hardware, or firmware), but rather providing insights on an IAB group's TTPs and the need for organizations to be aware of these types of attacks.

item.title: Researchers Uncover Batavia Windows Spyware Stealing Documents from Russian Firms
item.description:
The article describes two separate cyberattacks, one delivering Batavia Windows spyware and another delivering NordDragonScan Windows stealer malware. Both attacks use phishing emails to deliver malicious payloads that steal sensitive data from compromised hosts.
FYSA: Russian organizations have been targeted by a campaign delivering the previously undocumented Windows spyware called Batavia. The attack uses bait emails containing malicious links, which download an archive file containing a Visual Basic Encoded script (.VBE) file.

item.title: CISA Adds Four Critical Vulnerabilities to KEV Catalog Due to Active Exploitation
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Various; CVE(s): CVE-2014-3931, CVE-2016-10033, CVE-2019-5418, CVE-2019-9621; Summary: Four security flaws have been added to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog by CISA due to active exploitation. The vulnerabilities include a buffer overflow in MRLG, command injection in PHPMailer, path traversal in Ruby on Rails' Action View, and SSRF in Zimbra Collaboration Suite.

item.title: Alleged Chinese hacker tied to Silk Typhoon arrested for cyberespionage
item.description: A Chinese national, Xu Zewei, was arrested in Italy for allegedly being linked to the state-sponsored Silk Typhoon hacking group, responsible for cyberattacks against American organizations and government agencies. The group is accused of targeting infectious disease researchers and healthcare organizations, as well as the U.S. Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control and the Committee on Foreign Investment.

item.title: Unless users take action, Android will let Gemini access third-party apps
item.description: The article discusses the Google Gemini app's data collection capabilities and provides remedies for users who want to prevent data collection. Disabling app activity or uninstalling the app can be done through command-line terminal or using Android debug bridge, but some users may encounter errors like "DELETE_FAILED_INTERNAL_ERROR".

item.title: Public exploits released for Citrix Bleed 2 NetScaler flaw, patch now
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Citrix NetScaler; CVE(s): CVE-2025-5777; Summary: The CitrixBleed2 vulnerability allows attackers to retrieve memory contents by sending malformed POST requests during login attempts. This can lead to the theft of user session tokens and potentially exploit sensitive data.

item.title: Employee gets $920 for credentials used in $140 million bank heist
item.description:
The article reports a social engineering attack on an employee at C&M, a company that offers financial connectivity solutions. The attackers bribed the employee to gain access to confidential systems and steal nearly $140 million from six banks in Brazil. The incident highlights the importance of employee awareness and training in preventing such attacks.
FYSA: The article discusses a sophisticated social engineering attack on an employee at C&M, a company that offers financial connectivity solutions. The attackers bribed the employee to gain access to confidential systems and steal nearly $140 million from six banks in Brazil.

The specific flaw exists within the parsing of VPM files due to lack of proper validation of user-supplied data.

User interaction is required, as the target must visit a malicious page or open a malicious file. The issue results from the lack of proper validation of user-supplied data.

item.title: ZDI-25-482: (0Day) INVT VT-Designer PM3 File Parsing Out-Of-Bounds Write Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: INVT VT-Designer; CVE(s): CVE-2025-7231; Summary: This vulnerability allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected installations of INVT VT-Designer. It requires user interaction, such as visiting a malicious page or opening a malicious file, and is caused by the lack of proper validation of user-supplied data in the parsing of PM3 files.

item.title: Atomic macOS infostealer adds backdoor for persistent attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Atomic macOS Stealer; CVE(s): None; Summary: The Atomic macOS info-stealer (AMOS) has been updated with a backdoor, allowing attackers to execute arbitrary remote commands, survive reboots, and maintain control over infected hosts indefinitely. The malware can log keystrokes, introduce additional payloads, or perform lateral movement. It also features string obfuscation and checks for sandbox or virtual machine environments to evade detection.

item.title: No honor among thieves: M&S hacking group starts turf war
item.description: The article discusses a potential conflict between two ransomware groups, DragonForce and RansomHub, which could lead to increased risk of cyberattacks and double extortions. The instability in the extortion ecosystem can have serious implications for ransomware and data theft extortion victims. Additionally, the global cost of cybercrime is estimated to reach $10 trillion by 2025.

item.title: SEO Poisoning Campaign Targets 8,500+ SMB Users with Malware Disguised as AI Tools
item.description: Vulnerable Product: N/A; CVE(s): None; Summary: This article does not describe a vulnerability in any specific product. Instead, it discusses various malicious campaigns and tactics used by threat actors to spread malware, steal sensitive information, and commit financial fraud. The article highlights the use of search engine optimization (SEO) poisoning techniques, malvertising, and social engineering tactics to deliver malware loaders like Oyster, Vidar, Lumma, and Legion Loader.

item.title: Qantas is being extorted in recent data-theft cyberattack
item.description: Qantas has confirmed a cyberattack that potentially exposed 6 million customers' data, with threat actors demanding extortion. The attack did not expose financial information or sensitive details, but warned customers to be cautious of scams and phishing emails.

item.title: 'Batavia' Windows spyware campaign targets dozens of Russian orgs
item.description:
The article describes a previously undocumented spyware called "Batavia" that targets large industrial enterprises in Russia through phishing email campaigns. The malware has multiple stages, including profile gathering, data exfiltration, and additional payload downloads, indicating an espionage operation on Russia's industrial activity.
FYSA: The article highlights the effectiveness of simple techniques used by threat actors, even as cloud attacks become more sophisticated.

item.title: Hackers abuse leaked Shellter red team tool to deploy infostealers
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Shellter; CVE(s): None; Summary: Hackers used Shellter Elite, a commercial AV/EDR evasion loader for penetration testing, in attacks after a customer leaked a copy of the software. The misuse was discovered by security researchers and an update has been released to address the issue.

item.title: ZDI-25-473: Parallels Client Uncontrolled Search Path Element Local Privilege Escalation Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Parallels Client; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6812; Summary: This vulnerability allows local attackers to escalate privileges on affected installations of Parallels Client by exploiting an uncontrolled search path element in the AppServer service, which loads an OpenSSL configuration file from an unsecured location. An attacker must first obtain low-privileged code execution on the target system to exploit this vulnerability and execute arbitrary code in the context of a target user.

item.title: CISA Adds Four Known Exploited Vulnerabilities to Catalog
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Multiple products; CVE(s): CVE-2014-3931, CVE-2016-10033, CVE-2019-5418, CVE-2019-9621; Summary: The Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog has added four new vulnerabilities, including a Multi-Router Looking Glass Buffer Overflow, PHPMailer Command Injection, Rails Ruby on Rails Path Traversal, and Synacor Zimbra Collaboration Suite Server-Side Request Forgery. These vulnerabilities are frequently targeted by malicious actors and pose significant risks to the federal enterprise and other organizations.

item.title: Weekly Recap: Chrome 0-Day, Ivanti Exploits, MacOS Stealers, Crypto Heists and More
item.description:
This article appears to be a collection of various cybersecurity-related news and developments, covering topics such as malware attacks, phishing campaigns, data breaches, and security updates from major technology companies. There are no specific vulnerabilities mentioned in the article.
However, it's worth noting that the article does discuss some common attack vectors and tactics used by malicious actors, including smishing campaigns, email bombing, and file system redirection attacks. It also highlights the importance of robust cybersecurity measures and the need for organizations to stay vigilant against emerging threats.
Overall, while this article is not focused on a specific vulnerability, it provides valuable insights into the current state of cybersecurity and the types of threats that organizations may face in today's digital landscape.

item.title: Manufacturing Security: Why Default Passwords Must Go
item.description: The article highlights the risks associated with using default passwords in various devices and software systems. It emphasizes that default passwords provide an easy entry point for attackers, allowing them to recruit botnets, launch ransomware attacks, and compromise entire networks or partner systems.

item.title: SSO 0-Day & Fortinet Exploits, Allianz Breach, Social Media Ban Service Listed on Dark Web
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: Apereo CAS, Jasig, Keycloak with the CAS plugin; CVE(s): None; Summary: An alleged 0-day redirect vulnerability exists in major Single Sign-On (SSO) platforms, potentially allowing attackers to redirect users from trusted login portals to attacker-controlled domains, enabling phishing, session hijacking, or login bypass. The issue affects over 12,000 live systems across government, healthcare, finance, and international organizations.
FYSA: Threat actors are advertising exploits targeting known Fortinet CVEs (CVE-2024-55591) and a stolen database linked to Allianz Seguros Spain, potentially containing approximately 4.6 million records. Additionally, a social media ban service is being promoted, offering targeted takedowns across multiple platforms.

item.title: TAG-140 Deploys DRAT V2 RAT, Targeting Indian Government, Defense, and Rail Sectors
item.description: The article discusses the use of a modified variant of a remote access trojan (RAT) called DRAT V2, used by the threat actor TAG-140 to target Indian government organizations. The malware, which is part of an "interchangeable suite" of RATs, allows for harvesting sensitive data and complicates attribution, detection, and monitoring efforts.

item.title: OpenAI says GPT-5 will unify breakthroughs from different models
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: None; Summary: This article does not discuss a vulnerability. Instead, it provides information on OpenAI's plans to unify multiple models into one, creating GPT-5, and improves the existing models.
FYSA: Threat actors are using simple techniques to succeed in cloud attacks, with 8 key techniques revealed by Wiz's detections across thousands of organizations.

item.title: Hands on with Windows 11 Notepad's new markdown support
item.description: Vulnerable Product: None; Summary: This article is not about a vulnerability, but rather discusses the addition of markdown text formatting in Windows 11's Notepad app. The feature allows users to apply different formatting options such as headings, bold and italic styling, and hyperlinks.

item.title: ChatGPT is testing disruptive Study Together feature
item.description: Vulnerable Product: None; FYSA: The article does not contain information about a vulnerability. Instead, it discusses new features and updates related to OpenAI's ChatGPT, including the potential introduction of "Study together" mode, new connectors for GPT Search and Deep Research, and upcoming developments with GPT-5.

item.title: Ingram Micro outage caused by SafePay ransomware attack
item.description: The article reports on an ongoing outage at Ingram Micro caused by a SafePay ransomware attack. The attack led to the shutdown of internal systems and ransom notes were found on employee devices, although it's unclear if devices were actually encrypted.

item.title: Taiwan NSB Alerts Public on Data Risks from TikTok, Weibo, and RedNote Over China Ties
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Taiwan's National Security Bureau (NSB) warned about various Chinese-developed applications; CVE(s): None; Summary: The NSB detected excessive data collection, privacy infringement, and unauthorized data transmission from apps like RedNote, Weibo, TikTok, WeChat, and Baidu Cloud to China. These apps breached security indicators, including personal data collection, permission usage, data transmission, system information extraction, and biometric data access.

item.title: Alert: Exposed JDWP Interfaces Lead to Crypto Mining, Hpingbot Targets SSH for DDoS
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Multiple applications (TeamCity, Jenkins, Selenium Grid, Elasticsearch, Quarkus, Spring Boot, Apache Tomcat); CVE(s): None; Summary: Threat actors are exploiting exposed Java Debug Wire Protocol (JDWP) interfaces to obtain code execution capabilities and deploy cryptocurrency miners on compromised hosts.

item.title: ChatGPT Deep Research tests new connectors for more context
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: None; FYSA: The article discusses the integration of Slack with ChatGPT, a research AI agent. It mentions potential use cases for the integration, such as allowing ChatGPT to access an organization's chat and use messages in the context of research.
(Note: Since there is no vulnerability mentioned in the article, I summarized it using the FYSA format)

item.title: Ingram Micro suffers global outage as internal systems inaccessible
item.description: Ingram Micro's global outage impacting its websites and internal systems, with customers concerned it may be a cyberattack. The company remains silent on the cause of the issue. Some customers and employees claim the outage is due to a potential ransomware attack or breach, but this has not been confirmed.

item.title: Hacker leaks Telefnica data allegedly stolen in a new breach
item.description: This article is not about a vulnerability but rather reports on a potential data breach at Telefnica, a Spanish telecommunications company. The hacker, known as "Rey," claims to have stolen 106GB of internal data and has released a 2.6GB archive to prove the breach occurred.

item.title: NightEagle APT Exploits Microsoft Exchange Flaw to Target China's Military and Tech Sectors
item.description: No vulnerability is mentioned in this article. Instead, it discusses a threat actor called NightEagle (APT-Q-95) that targets Microsoft Exchange servers as part of a zero-day exploit chain to gather intelligence from government, defense, and technology sectors in China. The attackers use a bespoke version of the Chisel utility and implant a Trojan into the Internet Information Server (IIS) service of the Microsoft Exchange Server to gain unauthorized access.

item.title: Your AI Agents Might Be Leaking Data Watch this Webinar to Learn How to Stop It
item.description: Vulnerable Product: N/A; CVE(s): None; Summary: This article is not about a specific vulnerability, but rather highlights the potential risks of using generative AI (GenAI) systems without proper access controls, governance policies, and oversight. It discusses how well-meaning AI agents can unintentionally leak sensitive data to the wrong users or the internet, and emphasizes the importance of securing AI agents to prevent data exposure.

item.title: Critical Sudo Vulnerabilities Let Local Users Gain Root Access on Linux, Impacting Major Distros
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Sudo; CVE(s): CVE-2025-32462, CVE-2025-32463; Summary: Two security flaws were discovered in Sudo, a command-line utility for Linux and Unix-like operating systems. The vulnerabilities allow local attackers to escalate their privileges to root on susceptible machines. CVE-2025-32462 enables listed users to execute commands on unintended machines, while CVE-2025-32463 allows local users to obtain root access by using the --chroot option with a user-controlled directory.

item.title: Google Ordered to Pay $314M for Misusing Android Users' Cellular Data Without Permission
item.description: Google has been ordered by a California court to pay $314 million over allegations that it misused Android device users' cellular data when idle, sending information to the company without permission. The verdict marks an end to a legal class-action complaint filed in 2019.

item.title: Leaks hint at Operator-like tool in ChatGPT ahead of GPT-5 launch
item.description: Vulnerable Product: None; FYSA: There are no cybersecurity-relevant vulnerabilities or threats discussed in this article. Instead, it appears to be a collection of unrelated news and updates about OpenAI's ChatGPT and cloud security. The article mentions the possibility of an "Operator-like tool" being developed by OpenAI, but does not provide any information about potential vulnerabilities.

item.title: ZDI-25-469: Delta Electronics CNCSoft Screen Editor DPB File Parsing Out-Of-Bounds Write Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Delta Electronics CNCSoft Screen Editor; CVE(s): CVE-2025-47724; Summary: This vulnerability allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected installations of Delta Electronics CNCSoft. User interaction is required to exploit this vulnerability, and the specific flaw exists within the parsing of DPB files by the Screen Editor module due to lack of proper validation of user-supplied data.

item.title: ZDI-25-470: Delta Electronics CNCSoft Screen Editor DPB File Parsing Out-Of-Bounds Write Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Delta Electronics CNCSoft Screen Editor; CVE(s): CVE-2025-47725; Summary: This vulnerability allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected installations of Delta Electronics CNCSoft. User interaction is required to exploit this vulnerability, as the target must visit a malicious page or open a malicious file. The specific flaw exists within the parsing of DPB files by the Screen Editor module due to lack of proper validation of user-supplied data.

item.title: ZDI-25-471: Delta Electronics CNCSoft Screen Editor DPB File Parsing Out-Of-Bounds Write Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Delta Electronics CNCSoft Screen Editor; CVE(s): CVE-2025-47727; Summary: This vulnerability allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected installations of Delta Electronics CNCSoft by parsing DPB files without proper validation of user-supplied data, resulting in a write past the end of an allocated data structure. User interaction is required to exploit this vulnerability, requiring the target to visit a malicious page or open a malicious file.

item.title: ZDI-25-472: Delta Electronics CNCSoft Screen Editor DPB File Parsing Out-Of-Bounds Write Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Delta Electronics CNCSoft Screen Editor; CVE(s): CVE-2025-47726; Summary: The vulnerability allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected installations of Delta Electronics CNCSoft, requiring user interaction. It exists within the parsing of DPB files by the Screen Editor module due to lack of proper validation of user-supplied data, resulting in a write past the end of an allocated data structure.

item.title: ZDI-25-467: GStreamer H266 Codec Parsing Stack-based Buffer Overflow Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: GStreamer; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6663; Summary: This vulnerability allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected installations of GStreamer. The specific flaw exists within the parsing of H266 sei messages, resulting from a lack of proper validation of user-supplied data prior to copying it to a fixed-length stack-based buffer.

item.title: ZDI-25-468: GFI Archiver Telerik Web UI Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: GFI, Archiver; CVE(s): CVE-2019-18935, CVE-2017-11317, CVE-2014-2217; Summary: This vulnerability allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected installations of GFI Archiver. Authentication is not required to exploit this vulnerability, and the issue results from the use of a vulnerable version of Telerik Web UI.

item.title: Provider of covert surveillance app spills passwords for 62,000 users
item.description: The article reports on a stalkerware service called Catwatchful that has a hidden backdoor allowing users to uninstall the app by inputting specific numbers on their device's keyboard. The app uploads content in real-time and can be viewed from a web dashboard, and the service's operators were identified through a database dump.

item.title: xAI prepares Grok 4 Code as it plans to take on Claude and Gemini
item.description: The article discusses the upcoming release of Grok 4, a new state-of-the-art language model from xAI. It also highlights various cloud-based threat actor techniques used to launch attacks on organizations. Additionally, the article mentions other AI-related updates and releases from Google and Vibe coding company.

item.title: A message from Bruce the mechanical shark
item.description:
FYSA:
The article is a mix of cybersecurity-related content and non-security related information. The main focus is on cybersecurity, with discussions about phishing attacks, email threat detection engine updates, and malicious PowerShell scripts. Additionally, the article touches on a data breach at Ahold Delhaize, Europol's dismantling of a cryptocurrency fraud network, and an international cyberattack against the International Criminal Court.
However, the article also includes non-security related content, such as a nostalgic story about the movie "Jaws" and its mechanical shark, Bruce. The article concludes with a mention of upcoming conferences and events in the cybersecurity industry. Overall, the article is a collection of various topics, with some being more cybersecurity-focused than others.

item.title: Police dismantles investment fraud ring stealing 10 million
item.description: The article discusses a large-scale investment fraud operation that was dismantled by the Spanish police, resulting in the arrest of 21 individuals and the confiscation of luxury vehicles and cash. The scammers used tactics similar to "romance baiting" scams, luring victims into fake investments through social media ads and manipulated websites.

item.title: Grafana releases critical security update for Image Renderer plugin
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Grafana Image Renderer and Synthetic Monitoring Agent; CVE(s): CVE-2025-5959, CVE-2025-6554, CVE-2025-6191, CVE-2025-6192; Summary: Four high-severity Chromium vulnerabilities have been addressed in critical security updates for the Grafana Image Renderer plugin and Synthetic Monitoring Agent. The issues allow remote code execution, arbitrary memory read/write, out-of-bounds memory access, and heap corruption exploitable via crafted HTML pages.

item.title: Big Techs Mixed Response to U.S. Treasury Sanctions
item.description: Liu "Steve" Lizhi, a 40-year-old Chinese national, was sanctioned by the U.S. Department of the Treasury for operating a cloud provider linked to virtual currency investment scams known as "pig butchering." Despite being sanctioned, Lizhi maintains active accounts on Facebook, GitHub, PayPal, and Twitter/X, which continue to operate without issue. The article highlights concerns that big tech companies are not doing enough to cut ties with sanctioned individuals like Lizhi, potentially putting users at risk of financial losses.

item.title: Massive Android Fraud Operations Uncovered: IconAds, Kaleidoscope, SMS Malware, NFC Scams
item.description:
The article discusses several mobile ad fraud operations, including IconAds, Kaleidoscope, NGate, SuperCard X, and Qwizzserial. These operations involve the distribution of malicious apps through various means, including third-party app stores, fake websites, and social media platforms. The malware targets Android devices and steals user data, injects ads, and conducts fraudulent transactions.
FYSA: IconAds, a mobile ad fraud operation, has been disrupted by HUMAN. Kaleidoscope is another ad fraud scheme that uses the "evil twin" technique to distribute malicious apps. NGate and SuperCard X are malware families that abuse NFC technology for financial fraud. Qwizzserial is an SMS stealer that targets users in Uzbekistan.

item.title: IdeaLab confirms data stolen in ransomware attack last year
item.description: IdeaLab, a California-based technology startup incubator, has been impacted by a data breach incident where hackers accessed sensitive information. The Hunters International ransomware group claimed the breach and leaked the stolen data on the dark web, affecting current and former employees, contractors, and their dependents.

item.title: Microsoft investigates ongoing SharePoint Online access issues
item.description:
FYSA:
The article reports on an ongoing incident affecting SharePoint Online, a cloud-based collaboration platform. Users are experiencing intermittent access issues, with errors such as "Something went wrong." Microsoft is investigating the root cause of the issue, which appears to be related to authentication-related cookies. The company has not disclosed the affected regions or extent of the issue but has suggested possible workarounds using incognito mode.

item.title: CVE-2025-20309: Cisco Unified CM Flaw Enables Remote Root Access
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Cisco Unified Communications Manager platforms; CVE(s): CVE-2025-20309; Summary: A vulnerability in the static root account credentials allows an attacker to access a vulnerable device via SSH without authentication, granting full system compromise. This could enable deeper lateral movement across the network and jeopardize the integrity and confidentiality of communication platforms.

item.title: Microsoft: Exchange Server Subscription Edition now available
item.description: Microsoft has announced the availability of Exchange Server Subscription Edition (SE) to all customers, which introduces changes to licensing and servicing. The new edition will be an evergreen release with continuous support, replacing previous versions that will reach end-of-life soon.

item.title: Mitsubishi Electric MELSOFT Update Manager
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Mitsubishi Electric MELSOFT Update Manager; CVE(s): CVE-2024-11477, CVE-2025-0411; Summary: The MELSOFT Update Manager contains an Integer Underflow vulnerability in 7-zip that could allow a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code, disclose or alter information, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) condition. Additionally, there is a Protection Mechanism Failure vulnerability that could also lead to the same impacts.

item.title: CISA Releases Four Industrial Control Systems Advisories
item.description: CISA has released four Industrial Control Systems (ICS) advisories on July 3, 2025, providing information about current security issues, vulnerabilities, and exploits surrounding ICS. The advisories are specific to certain products from Hitachi Energy and Mitsubishi Electric.

item.title: Hitachi Energy MicroSCADA X SYS600
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Hitachi Energy MicroSCADA X SYS600; CVE(s): CVE-2025-39201, CVE-2025-39202, CVE-2025-39203, CVE-2025-39204, CVE-2025-39205; Summary: The product contains multiple vulnerabilities that could allow an attacker to tamper with system files, overwrite files, create a denial-of-service condition, or leak file content. Successful exploitation of these vulnerabilities could have severe impacts, including data corruption and unauthorized access.

item.title: Hitachi Energy Relion 670/650 and SAM600-IO Series
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Hitachi Energy Relion 670/650 and SAM600-IO series, Hitachi Energy; CVE(s): CVE-2025-1718; Summary: An authenticated user with file access privilege via FTP access can cause the devices to reboot due to improper disk space management. The vulnerability has a CVSS v4 score of 7.1 and affects various versions of the products.

item.title: Mitsubishi Electric MELSEC iQ-F Series
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Mitsubishi Electric Corporation MELSEC iQ-F Series; CVE(s): CVE-2025-5241; Summary: A denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability exists in the MELSEC iQ-F series due to an overly restrictive account lockout mechanism. A remote attacker could lockout a legitimate user for a certain period of time by repeatedly attempting to login with an incorrect password.

item.title: Hunters International ransomware shuts down after World Leaks rebrand
item.description: The Hunters International Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) operation has officially closed down and will offer free decryptors to help victims recover their data without paying a ransom.

item.title: Over 40 Malicious Firefox Extensions Target Cryptocurrency Wallets, Stealing User Assets
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: Mozilla Firefox; CVE(s): None; Summary: The article describes a large-scale campaign involving over 40 malicious browser extensions for Mozilla Firefox, designed to steal cryptocurrency wallet secrets. The extensions impersonate legitimate wallet tools and employ tactics such as artificially inflating their popularity and cloning open-source code to extract wallet keys and seed phrases from targeted websites.
FYSA: The article highlights a sophisticated threat actor group using a low-effort, high-impact approach to steal users' digital assets by distributing malicious browser extensions. The campaign's success relies on the ability of these extensions to operate inside the user's browser, making them harder to detect or block with traditional endpoint tools.

item.title: The Hidden Weaknesses in AI SOC Tools that No One Talks About
item.description: The article discusses the limitations of pre-trained AI models in security operations centers (SOCs) and highlights the benefits of adaptive AI, which learns to triage and respond to any alert type. Adaptive AI uses semantic classification, research agents, and multiple large language models to provide accurate, efficient, and context-aware triage. It also enables continuous learning and improvement by benchmarking model performance on real-world SOC tasks.

item.title: Microsoft asks users to ignore Windows Firewall config errors
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft, Windows Firewall; CVE(s): None; Summary: The June 2025 preview update of Windows causes incorrect Windows Firewall errors to appear in the Event Viewer after system reboots. These errors are logged as 'Event 2042' and can be safely ignored as they do not impact any Windows processes.

item.title: Apache Under the Lens: Tomcats Partial PUT and Camels Header Hijack
item.description:
FYSA:
The article discusses multiple vulnerabilities in Apache Tomcat and Apache Camel, including CVE-2025-24813, CVE-2025-27636, and CVE-2025-29891. The vulnerabilities allow for potential remote code execution, which can lead to data breaches and lateral movement within the network.
The analysis reveals that most of the exploit attempts use a six-character session name and a specific value for the Content-Range header. The Nuclei Scanner, a freely available scanner, is being used by attackers to check for the vulnerability.
Palo Alto Networks customers are protected from these threats through various products, including the Next Generation Firewall with an Advanced Threat Prevention subscription, Advanced URL Filtering, and Cortex Xpanse.
The article also highlights the importance of immediate action in addressing these vulnerabilities, as they can be exploited by less-skilled adversaries.

item.title: Chinese Hackers Exploit Ivanti CSA Zero-Days in Attacks on French Government, Telecoms
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Ivanti Cloud Services Appliance (CSA) devices; CVE(s): CVE-2024-8963, CVE-2024-9380, and CVE-2024-8190; Summary: A Chinese hacking group, codenamed Houken, exploited zero-day vulnerabilities in Ivanti CSA devices to gain access to target networks. The attackers used a rootkit and various tools to maintain persistence and conduct reconnaissance, with the goal of selling valuable data to state-linked actors or conducting lucrative operations.

item.title: Critical Cisco Vulnerability in Unified CM Grants Root Access via Static Credentials
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Cisco Unified Communications Manager; CVE(s): CVE-2025-20309; Summary: A maximum-severity vulnerability in Cisco Unified Communications Manager (Unified CM) and Unified Communications Manager Session Management Edition (Unified CM SME) allows an attacker to log in as the root user, gaining elevated privileges. The flaw is due to static user credentials for the root account and can be exploited by using the account to log in to an affected system, allowing the attacker to execute arbitrary commands as the root user.

item.title: NimDoor crypto-theft macOS malware revives itself when killed
item.description: North Korean state-backed hackers are using a new family of macOS malware called NimDoor in a campaign targeting web3 and cryptocurrency organizations. The attack chain involves contacting victims via Telegram, delivering fake Zoom SDK updates via Calendly and email, and deploying a persistence mechanism that uses signal-based techniques to ensure the malware remains active even after attempts to terminate it.

item.title: AT&T rolls out Wireless Account Lock protection to curb the SIM-swap scourge
item.description: Vulnerable Product: AT&T; CVE(s): None; Summary: The article discusses SIM-swap scams targeting cryptocurrency and bank account holders who store large sums of digital coin. Criminals take control of phone numbers to trigger password resets, draining accounts. AT&T's Wireless Account Lock feature prevents changes to SIM cards until it is manually turned off again, aiming to curb these types of scams.

item.title: DOJ investigates ex-ransomware negotiator over extortion kickbacks
item.description: A former employee of DigitalMint, a company that specializes in ransomware negotiation and cryptocurrency payments, is under criminal investigation for allegedly working with ransomware gangs to profit from extortion payment deals. The investigation suggests potential abuse of business models that incentivize larger transaction volumes and higher transaction sizes.

item.title: Spain arrests hackers who targeted politicians and journalists
item.description: The Spanish police have arrested two individuals suspected of cybercrime, including data theft from the government and high-ranking officials. They allegedly leaked stolen data online to increase its value and were involved in selling access to databases and credentials. The arrests are part of a larger effort by the Spanish authorities to track and apprehend cybercriminals.

item.title: North Korean Hackers Target Web3 with Nim Malware and Use ClickFix in BabyShark Campaign
item.description:
The article discusses North Korean threat actors using malware written in Nim programming language to target Web3 and cryptocurrency-related businesses. The malware uses process injection technique, remote communications via wss protocol, and a novel persistence mechanism. It also includes social engineering tactics, such as scheduling Zoom meetings and executing AppleScript that acts as a delivery vehicle for a second-stage script.
FYSA: North Korean threat actors have been observed targeting Web3 and cryptocurrency-related businesses with malware written in Nim programming language. The attacks involve social engineering tactics, process injection technique, and remote communications via wss protocol.

item.title: Cisco warns that Unified CM has hardcoded root SSH credentials
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Cisco Unified Communications Manager (Unified CM) and Unified CM SME; CVE(s): CVE-2025-20309; Summary: The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-20309, is a backdoor account with static user credentials for the root account, allowing remote attackers to log in with root privileges. This flaw affects Cisco Unified CM and Unified CM SME releases 15.0.1.13010-1 through 15.0.1.13017-1, regardless of device configuration.

item.title: Citrix warns of login issues after NetScaler auth bypass patch
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: Citrix; CVE(s): CVE-2025-5777, CVE-2025-6543; Summary: The patch for recently disclosed vulnerabilities in NetScaler ADC and Gateway appliances may also break login pages due to the enabling of Content Security Policy (CSP) header by default. This can cause authentication bypass and denial-of-service attacks. Disabling the CSP header temporarily resolves the issue, but administrators are advised to reach out to Citrix Support if the problem persists.
FYSA: None

item.title: Forminator plugin flaw exposes WordPress sites to takeover attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: WPMU DEV Forminator; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6463; Summary: The Forminator plugin for WordPress is vulnerable to an unauthenticated arbitrary file deletion flaw, tracked as CVE-2025-6463. This high-severity vulnerability (CVSS 8.8 score) allows attackers to delete critical files, such as wp-config.php, and take over the site.

item.title: CVE-2025-49596: Critical Flaw in Anthropics MCP Inspector Leads to RCE
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Anthropic's MCP Inspector; CVE(s): CVE-2025-49596; Summary: The vulnerability in Anthropic's MCP Inspector allows Remote Code Execution (RCE) due to overly lenient security defaults, including unauthenticated connections and lack of encryption. This can lead to full control over affected machines, making it a critical issue that needs to be addressed promptly.

item.title: Microsoft fixes Print to PDF feature broken by Windows update
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Windows 11 24H2; CVE(s): None; Summary: The "Print to PDF" feature on Windows 11 24H2 systems is broken after installing the April 2025 preview update, causing the Microsoft Print to PDF printer to no longer appear under Settings and returning error code 0x800f0922.

item.title: Dozens of fake wallet add-ons flood Firefox store to drain crypto
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Firefox; CVE(s): None; Summary: More than 40 fake extensions in Firefox's official add-ons store are impersonating popular cryptocurrency wallets, stealing wallet credentials and sensitive data by sending stolen information to attacker-controlled servers. The extensions include malicious code that monitors for sensitive data inputs from the victim, checks for realistic wallet keys/seed phrases, and exfiltrates data.

item.title: Grok 4 spotted ahead of launch with special coding features
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: None; Summary: This article does not contain information about a specific vulnerability in software, hardware, or firmware.
FYSA: The article mentions xAI releasing Grok 4, which could potentially be the best model from the company. It also highlights that cloud attacks may be growing more sophisticated, but attackers still succeed with surprisingly simple techniques.

item.title: Microsoft: DNS issue blocks delivery of Exchange Online OTP codes
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft; CVE(s): None; Summary: Microsoft is experiencing DNS misconfiguration issues affecting OTP message delivery in Exchange Online, impacting some users who may not receive OTP emails for encrypted messages. The issue affects users with a process set up to perform DNS checks on incoming email messages.

item.title: CISA Adds One Known Exploited Vulnerability to Catalog
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Google Chromium V8; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6554; Summary: A type confusion vulnerability in Google Chromium V8 has been added to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog, indicating active exploitation. This type of vulnerability is a frequent attack vector for malicious cyber actors and poses significant risks to the federal enterprise.

item.title: That Network Traffic Looks Legit, But it Could be Hiding a Serious Threat
item.description: The article discusses the importance of multi-layered detection strategies in cybersecurity operations centers (SOCs) to detect and respond to evolving threats. It highlights the limitations of traditional endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions and introduces network detection and response (NDR) as a complementary approach that provides visibility into network-based attacks. The article also explains different types of detections, including signature-based, threat intelligence, malware detection, behavioral detection, machine learning, anomaly detection, and search-based detection.

item.title: CVE-2025-6554: Chromes New Zero-Day Under Active Exploitation
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Google Chrome; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6554; Summary: A high-severity type confusion vulnerability (CVE-2025-6554) in Google Chrome's V8 JavaScript engine allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on the victim's machine, potentially leading to full system compromise. The vulnerability is actively being exploited and affects all major desktop platforms running Chrome, including Windows, macOS, and Linux.

item.title: Hackers Using PDFs to Impersonate Microsoft, DocuSign, and More in Callback Phishing Campaigns
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered a surge in phishing campaigns impersonating popular brands, including Microsoft and Docusign. The attacks use social engineering tactics, such as telephone-oriented attack delivery (TOAD), where victims are tricked into calling phone numbers operated by threat actors. These calls often employ scripted call center tactics, hold music, and spoofed caller IDs to gain the victim's trust.

item.title: Windows Shortcut (LNK) Malware Strategies
item.description:
This article provides an in-depth analysis of different types of LNK malware, which are a type of Windows executable files that can be used to launch malicious payloads. The article discusses four main techniques used by attackers to execute overlay content, including using find/findstr, mshta, and PowerShell commands/intrinsics.
The article also provides information on how Palo Alto Networks customers can protect themselves from these types of threats through the use of certain products, such as Next-Generation Firewall with cloud-delivered security services and Advanced Threat Prevention. Additionally, the article mentions that Palo Alto Networks has shared its findings with fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members to rapidly deploy protections to their customers.
Overall, this article is a valuable resource for cybersecurity professionals looking to gain a deeper understanding of LNK malware and how to protect against these types of threats.

item.title: PDFs: Portable documents, or perfect deliveries for phish?
item.description: The article discusses the trend of brand impersonation in email threats using PDF payloads, including social engineering techniques such as TOAD (Telephone-Oriented Attack Delivery) and QR code phishing. It highlights the use of Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) numbers to remain anonymous and the reuse of phone numbers on consecutive days.

item.title: U.S. Sanctions Russian Bulletproof Hosting Provider for Supporting Cybercriminals Behind Ransomware
item.description: The U.S. Department of the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) has levied sanctions against Russia-based bulletproof hosting (BPH) service provider Aeza Group and its subsidiaries, along with four individuals linked to the company, for assisting threat actors in their malicious activities.

item.title: Vercel's v0 AI Tool Weaponized by Cybercriminals to Rapidly Create Fake Login Pages at Scale
item.description: Unknown threat actors are using Vercel's generative AI tool v0 to design fake sign-in pages that impersonate legitimate counterparts, creating convincing replicas of login pages. This allows low-skilled attackers to build phishing sites at scale without requiring coding skills.

item.title: Qantas discloses cyberattack amid Scattered Spider aviation breaches
item.description: Qantas detected a cyberattack on its third-party customer servicing platform, which contained customer data. Threat actors gained access to the platform after targeting a Qantas call centre and stole a "significant" amount of data, including names, email addresses, phone numbers, birth dates, and frequent flyer numbers.

item.title: AT&T rolls out "Wireless Lock" feature to block SIM swap attacks
item.description: This article is about a security feature called "Wireless Lock" launched by AT&T to protect customers from SIM swapping attacks. The feature prevents changes to account information and phone number porting while it's enabled, and has been rolled out to all AT&T customers.

item.title: US critical infrastructure exposed as feds worn of possible attacks from Iran
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Unitronics, Orpak SiteOmat, Red Lion, Tridium Niagara framework; CVE(s): None; Summary: Devices from these manufacturers ship or previously shipped with default credentials, making it easy for threat actors to access and exploit them. The devices are widely used in the US and can be exposed to internet scans. Proper configuration and strong passwords are recommended to harden control systems against attacks.

item.title: Microsoft open-sources VS Code Copilot Chat extension on GitHub
item.description: The article discusses Microsoft's decision to release the source code for the GitHub Copilot Chat extension for VS Code under the MIT license, providing transparency into the implementation of the chat-based coding assistant and telemetry collection mechanisms. This move is considered a milestone in Microsoft's plan to integrate AI features directly into the popular open-source code editor, with openness seen as superior from a security perspective.

item.title: Critical Vulnerability in Anthropic's MCP Exposes Developer Machines to Remote Exploits
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Anthropic Model Context Protocol (MCP) Inspector; CVE(s): CVE-2025-49596; Summary: The MCP Inspector contains a critical remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability that allows an attacker to gain complete access to the host by chaining a known security flaw affecting modern web browsers, dubbed 0.0.0.0 Day, with a cross-site request forgery (CSRF) vulnerability in Inspector. The vulnerability can be exploited by visiting a malicious website, which can execute arbitrary commands on the machine running the tool.

item.title: Kelly Benefits says 2024 data breach impacts 550,000 customers
item.description: The Kelly & Associates Insurance Group (dba Kelly Benefits) has suffered a data breach that compromised the personal information of 553,660 individuals. The breach is believed to have occurred between December 12-17 and may have exposed full names, Social Security numbers, tax ID numbers, dates of birth, medical information, health insurance information, and financial account information.

item.title: Aeza Group sanctioned for hosting ransomware, infostealer servers
item.description: The US Department of the Treasury has sanctioned Russian hosting company Aeza Group and four operators for allegedly providing services to ransomware gangs, infostealer operations, darknet drug markets, and Russian disinformation campaigns. The sanctions aim to disrupt these cybercriminal activities and prevent further exploitation of US-based assets.

item.title: New FileFix attack runs JScript while bypassing Windows MoTW alerts
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Windows; CVE(s): None; Summary: A new attack called FileFix allows executing malicious scripts by exploiting how browsers handle saved HTML webpages. The attack tricks users into saving an HTML page as ".HTA" and renaming it to auto-execute embedded JScript via mshta.exe, bypassing the Mark of the Web (MoTW) protection in Windows.

item.title: TA829 and UNK_GreenSec Share Tactics and Infrastructure in Ongoing Malware Campaigns
item.description: The article discusses the tactical similarities between two threat actor groups, TA829 and UNK_GreenSec, which have been observed delivering different malware strains. The article highlights their use of similar infrastructure, delivery tactics, and email lure themes to deliver malicious payloads.

item.title: International Criminal Court hit by new 'sophisticated' cyberattack
item.description: The International Criminal Court (ICC) is investigating a new "sophisticated" cyberattack that targeted its systems last week. The incident was contained through the ICC's alert and response mechanisms, but further details about the nature of the attack, impact, or any data exfiltration are not yet available. This is the second cyberattack targeting the ICC in recent years, following a breach in September 2023 attributed to cyber espionage.

item.title: Top 10 Free IoC Search & Enrichment Platforms
item.description: This article discusses the importance of Indicators of Compromise (IoCs) in cybersecurity and provides a list of 10 free platforms for searching and enriching IoCs. The platforms featured include AlienVault OTX, Pulsedive, AbuseIPDB, ThreatMiner, IOC Radar, threatfox, URLhaus, GreyNoise, MISP, VirusTotal, and ThreatBook. These platforms provide various capabilities such as search, enrichment, and integration with other security tools to help analysts detect and respond to threats.

item.title: US disrupts North Korean IT worker "laptop farm" scheme in 16 states
item.description: The U.S. Department of Justice (DoJ) took coordinated law enforcement actions against North Korea's fund-raising operations using remote IT workers, compromising the identities of over 80 U.S. citizens and generating more than $5 million in illicit revenue. Sensitive data, including US military tech regulated under ITAR, was accessed and exfiltrated by North Koreans.

item.title: New Flaw in IDEs Like Visual Studio Code Lets Malicious Extensions Bypass Verified Status
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Visual Studio Code; CVE(s): None; Summary: Flawed verification checks in Visual Studio Code allow attackers to add malicious functionality to extensions while maintaining a verified icon, enabling remote code execution and opening up a low-barrier entry point for attackers. The vulnerability can be exploited by creating a malicious extension with the same verifiable values as an already verified extension and bypassing trust checks.

item.title: Esse Health says recent data breach affects over 263,000 patients
item.description: Esse Health suffered a cyberattack that compromised personal and health information of over 263,000 patients. The attackers stole a wide range of sensitive data, including personal information, health insurance information, medical record numbers, and some health information.

item.title: CISA Adds Two Known Exploited Vulnerabilities to Catalog
item.description: Vulnerable Product: TeleMessage TM SGNL; CVE(s): CVE-2025-48927, CVE-2025-48928; Summary: Two vulnerabilities in TeleMessage TM SGNL have been added to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog due to evidence of active exploitation. These vulnerabilities pose significant risks to the federal enterprise and are frequent attack vectors for malicious cyber actors.

item.title: Voltronic Power and PowerShield UPS Monitoring Software
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Voltronic Power Viewpower, Voltronic Power ViewPower Pro, Powershield NetGuard; CVE(s): CVE-2022-31491, CVE-2021-43110; Summary: Successful exploitation of these vulnerabilities could allow an unauthenticated attacker remotely to make configuration changes, including shutting down connected UPS devices or execution of arbitrary code.

item.title: Hitachi Energy Relion 670/650 and SAM600-IO Series
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Hitachi Energy Relion 670/650 and SAM600-IO series devices; CVE(s): CVE-2025-2403; Summary: A denial-of-service vulnerability exists due to improper prioritization of network traffic over protection mechanism, allowing attackers to cause critical functions like LDCM (Line Distance Communication Module) to malfunction. Successful exploitation could disrupt critical functions in the device.

item.title: CISA Releases Seven Industrial Control Systems Advisories
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Multiple products from various vendors (FESTO, Hitachi Energy, Voltronic); CVE(s): None; Summary: CISA released seven ICS advisories covering vulnerabilities and exploits in industrial control systems products from FESTO, Hitachi Energy, and Voltronic. The advisories provide technical details and mitigation strategies for the identified issues.

item.title: FESTO Automation Suite, FluidDraw, and Festo Didactic Products
item.description: Vulnerable Product: FESTO, FESTO Didactic (various products); CVE(s): CVE-2023-3935; Summary: A heap buffer overflow vulnerability in Wibu CodeMeter Runtime network service allows an unauthenticated, remote attacker to achieve RCE and gain full access of the host system. Successful exploitation could allow an attacker to gain full control of the host system, including remote code execution.

item.title: Hitachi Energy MSM
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Hitachi Energy Modular Switchgear Monitoring (MSM); CVE(s): CVE-2020-11022; Summary: The vulnerability is a Cross-site Scripting issue that allows attackers to execute untrusted code, potentially leading to unauthorized actions or system compromise. Successful exploitation could be done remotely with low attack complexity.

item.title: FESTO Hardware Controller, Hardware Servo Press Kit
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Festo; CVE(s): CVE-2022-30311, CVE-2022-30310, CVE-2022-30309, CVE-2022-30308; Summary: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an OS Command ('OS Command Injection') vulnerabilities exist in multiple versions of Festo Controller CECC-X-M1 product family. Successful exploitation could allow unauthorized system command execution with root privileges.
